Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: The influence of climate change on biogeochemical processes in northern ecosystems: An international perspective in Earth System Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU program will focus on providing student research experiences in Earth System Science (ESS), with special emphasis on investigating the impacts of climate change on biogeochemical processes in northern upland and wetland ecosystems. In this multifaceted program, we will bring students for the first four weeks to the University of New Hampshire (UNH) to provide them with background knowledge of ESS and biogeochemistry and to train them in laboratory and field techniques. During that time they will work with a research mentor to develop research questions they will then explore during the second part of the program in the permafrost region of Northern Sweden. The participants will spend the second four weeks at the Abisko Scientific Research Station (ANS), Sweden. ANS is one of the few locations where it is well documented that climate warming is affecting the geochemical, hydrological and biological cycles. At ANS, the REU students will be fully integrated into an international scientific community as they collect samples and data to support their research projects. For the final two weeks of their REU program, the students will return to UNH to analyze their data, complete any requisite additional analyses, summarize their findings and present their research to their peers and mentors, and prepare to submit their research for presentation at an international scientific meeting.

This REU program will promote teaching, training and learning through the research process. The UNH-Abisko REU in Earth System Science extends these goals to provide students a systems perspective that emphasizes how aspects of the Earth system are impacted by climate change. This program will enhance the education of the next generation of scientists by giving them a foundation in interdisciplinary collaboration, an essential key in addressing emerging global environmental and energy policy issues. REU participants will also gain experience in communicating their scientific findings with an audience of non-specialists via coordinated visits with policy and education experts. In addition to student training, this ESS REU program provides integrative cross-disciplinary scientific activities and enhances the collaborative links between UNH and a world-class field site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2011, the University of New Hampshire launched its NSF REU Site (NSF # EAR 1063037) program, titled the Northern Ecosystems Research for Undergraduates (NERU). The central goal of the NERU program was to foster student development through a mentored research program focused on Earth System Science (ESS).

 

Specifically, we expected that the students would:

1. Conduct faculty mentored research in Earth System Science,

2. Develop research, collaboration and communication skills,

3. Enhance their appreciation of the international perspectives in ESS by exploring ESS research questions collaboratively, at a foreign research site.

 

The NERU program was a 10-week summer REU Site that provided student research experiences in Earth System Science, with a specific focus on investigation of the changing biological processes in northern upland and wetland ecosystems. Students spent the first 3 weeks of the program at UNH, where they worked with a faculty mentor to develop research questions and the requisite skills that they needed to conduct research during the four weeks of the residential program at the Abisko Scientific Research Station, located in the permafrost region of Northern Sweden. After this period in Sweden, the team returned to UNH for the final 3 weeks, during which time they further analyzed samples and data, synthesized their results, and presented their research posters at UNH’s Summer Research Symposium. The students also submitted abstracts to national science meetings such as the American Geophysical Union (AGU) meeting. NERU also supported students’ attendance at these conferences, if their abstracts were accepted.

 

In total, the NERU program was able to offer research and professional development opportunities to 37 undergraduates. In all, 62% of the NERU participants were female, eight (22%) of the participants participating in the survey identified themselves as members of underrepresented groups, one was a veteran, and seven were first generation/non-traditional students. In the first year, all 9 research projects were successfully completed, and presented at the Fall AGU Meeting. In year 2, all projects were completed, and 8 of the students presented at the AGU meeting, while two others presented at the Polar and Alpine Microbiology Conference in September, 2013. All students in years 3 and 4 presented their research at the AGU meeting. In addition to attending these high-profile international conferences, many students also presented at their own university’s undergraduate research conferences, and eight students used the research experience as their senior thesis. 

 

We are excited to report the following, significant outcomes related to participation in national and international programs, graduate school application and completion, applications for NSFGRFPs, and research publication:

  • Three students were selected to present at the NSF Council on Undergraduate Research’s REU meeting (2013-2015).
  • As of November, 2016, we have five manuscripts in preparation for publication, one in press and one in review.
  • At the time of this report, 62% of NERU participants (2012-2015) have enrolled in graduate programs (6 PhD and 17 MS; 2 have completed their MS degrees) and an additional 27% are either still in undergraduate programs, or in STEM internships or jobs, including international positions.

 

NERU focused not only on research skill development, but also supported the development of collaborative skills, communication of research to varied audiences, and understanding the broader societal impact of their work. We have supported the submission of 19 applications to the highly competitive NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program. Two NERU participants were awarded an NSF GRFP and there have been 3 honorable mentions. We also supported fellowship applications to NASA, DOE and DoD, resulting in one DoD National Defense Science and Engineering Graduate (NDSEG) Fellowship Program recipient. One NERU alumnus received the ESA Student Policy Award in 2016. Finally, we have had three applications to the US State Dept. Fulbright program that were all selected for funding. Students also reached out to other organizations for support of their ongoing research, and we had one successful proposal to the American Swedish Institute's Malmburg fellowship. 

 

In addition to the undergraduate participants, we had one high school chemistry teacher participate in the NERU program. This provided a novel professional development experience for the teacher, which led to new research experiences for her students. In all, 6 graduate students, 3 postdoctoral researchers, 3 laboratory technicians and 8 faculty participated, at varying levels of support, as mentors, and also provided a variety of technical and logistical support. Both established, and early career scientists participated in mentorship training specifically focused on supporting undergraduate students. Program evaluation indicates that the students placed a high level of value on the mentor/mentee relationship, and credited it in the success of their experience, and on their future career plans and/or further education.
